definitions: law or regulation enacted by local government or municipal authority with legal force
prescribed religious ceremony or sacrament in Christian churches
examples: The city council passed an ordinance prohibiting parking on main street
Local ordinances require businesses to obtain permits for outdoor seating
The church celebrates the ordinance of baptism every month
Communion and baptism are sacred ordinances in many denominations

definitions: state or quality of being normal, usual, or commonplace in nature
ecclesiastical judge with immediate jurisdiction in church matters
examples: Life returned to the ordinary after the holiday excitement ended
She found beauty in the ordinary moments of daily life
The bishop served as the ordinary for the entire diocese
Church law requires the ordinary to approve certain religious matters

definitions: ceremony of conferring holy orders or appointing someone as priest, minister, or rabbi
act of ordering, arranging, or decreeing something formally
examples: His ordination as a priest took place at the cathedral
The seminary prepared students for ordination into ministry
The ordination of these principles shaped constitutional law
Natural ordination creates patterns throughout the universe

definitions: mounted guns, artillery, and other heavy military weapons with their ammunition and equipment
military department responsible for storing and supplying weapons and ammunition
examples: The army depot stored heavy ordnance including artillery shells
Unexploded ordnance from past wars still poses dangers
The ordnance corps maintained all weaponry for the battalion
Military ordnance specialists handle explosive materials safely

definitions: naturally occurring rock or mineral from which metal or valuable minerals can be extracted
examples: The miners extracted iron ore from deep underground shafts
Copper ore requires extensive processing to yield pure metal
Gold ore contains only tiny amounts of actual gold
The smelter processes various ores into refined metals

definitions: aromatic Mediterranean herb with small leaves used fresh or dried in cooking
examples: She sprinkled dried oregano over the pizza before baking
Fresh oregano grows abundantly in the herb garden
Italian recipes often call for oregano and basil together
The oregano plant produces tiny white or purple flowers

definitions: chocolate sandwich cookie with white cream filling produced by Nabisco
examples: Children love dunking Oreos in cold milk after school
The recipe calls for crushed Oreos as pie crust
Double Stuf Oreos contain extra cream filling between cookies
She bought a package of Oreos from the grocery store

definitions: specialized body part that performs vital functions in living organisms
large keyboard instrument producing sound through pipes supplied with air
newspaper, magazine, or other medium serving as voice for particular group
examples: The heart pumps blood as the body's most vital organ
Doctors performed surgery to transplant the damaged organ
The church organ filled the cathedral with majestic music
She practiced Bach fugues on the pipe organ daily
The newsletter serves as the official organ of the society
Party organs published propaganda supporting government policies

definitions: substance or product produced without synthetic chemicals using natural growing methods
examples: The store specializes in organic produce from local farms
Organic cotton costs more but avoids harmful pesticides
She chose organic milk to avoid hormones and antibiotics
The restaurant sources organic ingredients whenever possible

definitions: group of people working together for shared purpose with defined structure
systematic arrangement or coordination of parts into ordered whole
examples: The charitable organisation helps homeless families find housing
International organisations coordinate disaster relief efforts worldwide
The organisation of files made research much more efficient
Poor organisation led to confusion during the event

definitions: person who arranges, coordinates, or manages events, activities, or groups
notebook, binder, or device used for planning and scheduling
examples: The event organiser coordinated vendors, venues, and volunteers
Union organisers helped workers negotiate better conditions
She kept her appointments in a leather-bound personal organiser
Digital organisers sync schedules across multiple devices

definitions: individual living thing capable of growth, reproduction, and response to environment
examples: Scientists discovered a new organism in deep ocean vents
Microscopic organisms play crucial roles in soil health
The human body hosts trillions of bacterial organisms
Each organism adapts uniquely to its ecological niche

definitions: musician who plays the organ, especially in church or concert settings
examples: The church organist played hymns during Sunday services
She studied for years to become a concert organist
The organist accompanied the choir with skillful improvisation
Cathedral organists often give recitals of classical works

definitions: group of people working together for shared purpose with defined structure
systematic arrangement or coordination of parts into ordered whole
examples: The humanitarian organization provides aid to refugees worldwide
Large organizations require complex management structures
The organization of data improved research efficiency significantly
Her excellent organization skills made the project succeed

definitions: person who arranges, coordinates, or manages events, activities, or groups
notebook, binder, or device used for planning and scheduling
examples: The conference organizer handled registration and speaker arrangements
Community organizers mobilized residents for the campaign
Her desk organizer keeps supplies neatly compartmentalized
The wall organizer holds mail, keys, and important papers

definitions: peak of sexual excitement characterized by intense pleasure and physiological responses
examples: Medical research studies physiological changes during orgasm
Some medications can affect the ability to reach orgasm
Therapists help couples address concerns about orgasm and intimacy
The book discusses orgasm from biological and psychological perspectives

definitions: wild party or event characterized by excessive indulgence in specified activity
examples: The shopping spree turned into an orgy of consumption
Critics described the film as an orgy of violence
The banquet became an orgy of eating and drinking
Media coverage created an orgy of speculation and rumors

definitions: countries of Asia, especially East Asia, viewed from Western perspective
examples: Merchants brought spices and silk from the Orient
Western fascination with the Orient influenced art and literature
The museum features ancient treasures from the Orient
Trade routes connected Europe with the mysterious Orient

definitions: position or alignment relative to points of compass or other reference
process of introducing newcomers to organization, role, or environment
person's basic attitudes, beliefs, or feelings regarding particular subject
examples: The building's orientation maximizes natural light throughout the day
Map orientation helps hikers navigate unfamiliar terrain
New employee orientation covers company policies and procedures
Freshman orientation helps students adjust to college life
The program respects each individual's political orientation
Sexual orientation forms part of personal identity

definitions: opening or hole, especially natural opening in the body
examples: The doctor examined each orifice during the medical checkup
Natural orifices allow substances to enter or exit organs
The volcanic orifice emitted steam and sulfurous gases
Small orifices in the membrane permit selective flow

definitions: Japanese art of folding paper into decorative shapes and figures without cutting
examples: She created beautiful origami cranes for the wedding decorations
Children learned basic origami techniques in art class
Complex origami designs require precise folding and patience
The museum displayed intricate origami sculptures by master artists

definitions: point or place where something begins, arises, or derives from
person's social background, ancestry, or cultural heritage
examples: Scientists traced the virus origin to a specific region
The river's origin lies high in the mountain springs
Her Caribbean origin influenced her cooking style significantly
Products must clearly label their country of origin

definitions: first or earliest form of something from which copies are made
work of art, literature, or music created directly by artist
examples: The museum displays the original manuscript of the constitution
She kept the original receipt for warranty purposes
The gallery sells only original paintings, not reproductions
His original compositions blend classical and jazz elements

definitions: quality of being novel, fresh, or unusual in creation or thought
examples: The designer's originality earned international recognition and awards
Academic work requires both research rigor and originality
Her originality in solving problems impressed the entire team
The film lacks originality, recycling tired plot devices

definitions: act or process of bringing something into existence or initiating something
examples: The loan origination process requires extensive documentation
Scientists study the origination of species through evolution
The origination of this tradition dates back centuries
Banks charge fees for mortgage origination services

definitions: person who creates, invents, or initiates something new
examples: The originator of the theory won the Nobel Prize
Patent law protects originators of innovative designs
She was the originator of the company's expansion strategy
The loan originator processes mortgage applications for clients

definitions: brightly colored songbird with black and yellow or orange plumage
examples: Baltimore orioles build hanging nests in tall trees
The oriole's melodious song filled the morning air
Orioles migrate south to Central America each winter
She spotted a hooded oriole at the hummingbird feeder

definitions: object used to make something more attractive but usually having no practical purpose
examples: She carefully wrapped each Christmas ornament before storage
The mantelpiece displayed delicate porcelain ornaments
Garden ornaments added whimsy to the landscape design
The tree sparkled with glass ornaments and tinsel

definitions: plant, object, or feature serving decorative rather than practical purpose
examples: The garden features ornamental grasses and flowering shrubs
Ornamental ironwork decorated the historic building's facade
She collected ornamental plates from various countries
The pond includes ornamental koi fish and water lilies

definitions: decorative elements added to enhance appearance of objects, buildings, or music
examples: Baroque architecture features elaborate ornamentation on every surface
The singer added vocal ornamentation to the simple melody
Excessive ornamentation can overwhelm the basic design
Celtic manuscripts display intricate ornamentation in the margins

definitions: scientist who studies birds, their behavior, physiology, and classification
examples: The ornithologist documented rare species in the rainforest
Ornithologists use banding to track bird migration patterns
She became an ornithologist after years of amateur birdwatching
The ornithologist published findings on avian communication

definitions: scientific study of birds including their physiology, classification, and behavior
examples: She earned her doctorate in ornithology from Cornell University
Ornithology combines field observation with laboratory research
The museum's ornithology department houses thousands of specimens
Advances in ornithology revealed surprising bird intelligence

definitions: child whose parents are dead or have permanently abandoned them
examples: The orphan found a loving home with adoptive parents
War creates thousands of orphans needing care and protection
The novel tells the story of an orphan's journey
Charitable organizations support orphans through education programs

definitions: residential institution for the care and education of orphaned children
examples: The orphanage provided shelter for hundreds of children
Donations help the orphanage buy food and school supplies
She volunteered at the local orphanage every weekend
The old orphanage building was converted into apartments

definitions: authorized or generally accepted theory, doctrine, or practice in religion or other field
examples: Scientific orthodoxy once rejected continental drift theory
He challenged the economic orthodoxy of his time
Religious orthodoxy maintains traditional interpretations of scripture
The artist rebelled against artistic orthodoxy and convention

definitions: regular back and forth movement between two positions or states
examples: The pendulum's oscillation keeps precise time in the clock
Scientists measured oscillations in the electromagnetic field
Market prices showed rapid oscillation throughout the trading day
The oscillation between hope and despair exhausted him

definitions: large raptor that feeds almost exclusively on fish, found near water worldwide
examples: The osprey dove into the lake to catch a trout
Ospreys build large stick nests on tall platforms
Conservation efforts helped osprey populations recover from pesticide damage
An osprey circled above the river searching for fish

definitions: exclusion from a group or society by general consent or social rejection
examples: Social ostracism can cause severe psychological harm
The whistleblower faced ostracism from former colleagues
Ancient Athens used ostracism to exile dangerous citizens
Workplace ostracism affects employee mental health significantly

definitions: largest living bird native to Africa, unable to fly but capable of fast running
examples: The ostrich can run up to forty miles per hour
Ostrich eggs are the largest of any living bird
The farm raises ostriches for their meat and leather
An ostrich uses its powerful legs for defense

definitions: realm of supernatural beings or afterlife in mythology and religious belief
examples: Celtic mythology describes journeys to the otherworld
The shaman claimed to travel between this world and otherworld
Stories tell of heroes visiting the otherworld and returning
The otherworld appears differently in various cultural traditions

definitions: carnivorous mammal with webbed feet and dense fur, living near water
examples: Sea otters float on their backs while eating shellfish
The river otter playfully slid down the muddy bank
Otters use tools to crack open shells on rocks
A family of otters made their home near the pond

definitions: low upholstered seat or footstool without back or arms
member or aspect of the Turkish empire that lasted from 1299 to 1922
examples: She propped her feet on the leather ottoman while reading
The storage ottoman opens to reveal blankets inside
Ottoman architecture influenced building styles across the empire
The Ottoman Empire once controlled vast territories

definitions: unit of weight equal to one sixteenth of a pound or about 28 grams
very small amount or portion of something
examples: The recipe calls for eight ounces of chocolate chips
Gold prices are quoted per troy ounce
She didn't have an ounce of sympathy for him
Every ounce of effort counts in this competition

definitions: act of forcing someone out of position, property, or place
examples: The board voted for the CEO's ouster after the scandal
The military ouster of the president sparked protests
Legal proceedings led to the tenant's ouster from the property
His ouster from the committee surprised many members

definitions: act or process of forcing someone from position or place
examples: The ousting of corrupt officials improved public trust
Shareholders demanded the ousting of incompetent management
The ousting took months of legal proceedings to complete
Political ousting often leads to instability and uncertainty

definitions: period when power supply or other service is not available
examples: The power outage lasted three hours during the storm
Internet outages disrupted business operations across the city
Scheduled outages allow for essential maintenance work
The outage affected thousands of customers

definitions: remote and sparsely inhabited interior region, especially of Australia
examples: They drove for days through the Australian outback
The outback station was hundreds of miles from town
Wildlife thrives in the harsh outback environment
Outback communities rely on flying doctor services

definitions: portable motor attached to outside of boat's stern for propulsion
examples: The fishing boat uses a powerful outboard motor
She started the outboard and headed across the lake
Outboard motors require regular maintenance for reliability
The outboard can be tilted up in shallow water

definitions: sudden occurrence or eruption of something unpleasant, especially disease or conflict
examples: Health officials contained the measles outbreak quickly
The outbreak of war disrupted international trade
An outbreak of food poisoning affected dozens of diners
The region experienced an outbreak of violent protests

definitions: building separate from but belonging to a main house or property
examples: The farm's outbuildings include a barn and tool shed
They converted an old outbuilding into a guest cottage
Historic outbuildings surround the main manor house
The outbuilding serves as a workshop and storage area
